input: Hello doctor,My inside part of my right elbow has been sore and swollen for five months. Flexing my arm out and wrist up and turning my arm from side to side aggravates things quite badly. Pain is worse at night time. When I push my three fingers and thumb together I get radiating pain down my forearm into my inside part of my elbow. Ultrasound showed all is good, but something is going on. It is hard to use my arm for any strength activities. My GP and physiotherapist have told it is not tendinitis. I took Ibuprofen and Voltarin Samuel gel but made no difference to the pain.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,My inside part of my right elbow has been sore and swollen for five months. Flexing my arm out and wrist up and turning my arm from side to side aggravates things quite badly. Pain is worse at night time. When I push my three fingers and thumb together I get radiating pain down my forearm into my inside part of my elbow. Ultrasound showed all is good, but something is going on. It is hard to use my arm for any strength activities. My GP and physiotherapist have told it is not tendinitis. I took Ibuprofen and Voltarin Samuel gel but made no difference to the pain.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is possible that they are experiencing symptoms of lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow. This condition is characterized by pain and swelling on the outside of the elbow, which is aggravated by wrist movements and gripping objects.

However, since the ultrasound showed no abnormalities, it is important to consider other potential causes of the symptoms. These may include:

1. Medial epicondylitis: This is a less common condition where the pain is located on the inside of the elbow, rather than the outside. It can be caused by repetitive forearm movements.

2. Ulnar nerve entrapment: The ulnar nerve can become compressed or irritated at the elbow, leading to pain and weakness in the arm. This condition may be aggravated by flexing the arm and wrist.

3. Bursitis: Inflammation of the bursae, small fluid-filled sacs that reduce friction between tissues, can cause pain and swelling in the elbow.

4. Cubital tunnel syndrome: Compression of the ulnar nerve as it passes through the cubital tunnel (inside the elbow) can result in symptoms similar to those described by the patient.

To

input: Hello doctor,I am a 49-year-old woman. I am suffering from severe anemia (iron and B12 deficiency). This might be the result of prolonged malnutrition over the past few years. The problem is that I have developed extreme sensitivity to most of the drugs, medication, treatment. In the past, there were many instances of adverse reactions by taking medicines of Iron composition. These include restlessness, breathing problem, and diarrhea. About five years ago, upon the doctor's advice and supervision, I was fed intravenously through saline bottle with some Iron injection to it. Immediately in about 15 minutes after the procedure, I experienced shortness of breath, burning sensation in muscles, swelling of legs, fatigue, and diarrhea. It subsided when I was given an antidote by the doctor immediately. From then onwards I was reluctant to take any of my medicines and undergo any treatment. I just focussed on improving my diet. Recently upon doctor's advice, I took some medical tests and the reports were serum ferritin: 3.0 ng/mL, vitamin B12: 129 pg/mL, TSH: 0.02 \xb5IU/mL (but T3/T4 tests are fine), iron: 15 \xb5g/dL, TIBC: 527 \xb5g/dL, hemoglobin 7.7 g/dL, vitamin D: 18.39 ng/mL. I was also informed that I developed food allergy to some foods. Lately, I am experiencing a headache with activity, unexplained generalized weakness, fatigue most of the time. According to the doctor, I am in a very critical position and should be immediately treated with Iron injections, blood transfusion, etc. But, I am really worried as my body will not be able to take these treatments (as I faced adverse reactions in the past). Are there any medical procedures or treatments on which I can rely upon ensuring that they will not have any adverse effects after the treatment. Please help me.

Also there was a CRL measurement of 26.96. My due date based on LMP and ultrasound are different. Please answer. Also how many "safe" days are there after a period?

### Response:To figure out your conception date, you can subtract 9 weeks and 3 days from your current gestational age (GA) of 12 weeks and 5 days. This will give you a estimated conception date of around 3 weeks and 4 days ago.

The discrepancy between your due date based on LMP and ultrasound is common and can occur due to various factors such as irregular menstrual cycles or imprecise dating of the LMP. It's important to note that the due date calculated from an ultrasound measurement is more accurate than the one calculated from LMP alone.

As for how many "safe" days there are after a period, it is generally recommended to use condoms or other forms of contraception immediately after your period if you do not want to get pregnant. There is no such thing as specifically "safe" days during the menstrual cycle for unprotected sex.

input: Hello doctor,My husband and I will be using a surrogate to have kids. My husband is kell positive (heterozygous). What are the risks to this that the surrogate would need to be aware of?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,My husband and I will be using a surrogate to have kids. My husband is kell positive (heterozygous). What are the risks to this that the surrogate would need to be aware of?

### Response:Hello,

Thank you for your question. If your husband is heterozygous for the Kell blood group system, there is a risk of alloimmunization during pregnancy. This means that if the surrogate carries a baby for your husband, her immune system may recognize the paternal blood cells as foreign and mount an immune response. This could potentially lead to complications such as hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN).

The specific risks that the surrogate would need to be aware of include:

1. Antibody formation: If the surrogate carries a Kell-positive father's baby, her immune system may produce antibodies against the Kell antigens present on the father's blood cells. This can cause problems for future pregnancies if the surrogate carries a Kell-positive father's baby again.

2. HDN: The maternal immune response to the paternal blood cells can result in the breakdown of red blood cells in the baby. This can cause anemia, jaundice, and other complications.

To minimize these risks, it is important for both you and your husband to inform the surrogate about the potential dangers and consult with a medical professional who specializes in reproductive medicine. They can guide you through appropriate testing

input: Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population may not be detected using the standard methods employed. Could you please explain what does it mean? What can be done for her? Will she be able to have kids?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,My sister is 18 years old, and she has never had periods. Recently, we did a test which said, 46, XY (20), 20 cells were counted, all cells showed 46 chromosomes. Small chromosomal anomalies and small clonal population may not be detected using the standard methods employed. Could you please explain what does it mean? What can be done for her? Will she be able to have kids?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it appears that your sister has a chromosomal abnormality known as Turner syndrome. This condition occurs in females when one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially deleted. The karyotyping test result of 46, XY indicates the presence of an extra Y chromosome, which is typically found in males.

The small chromosomal anomalies and clonal population mentioned in the report suggest that there may be additional genetic changes that were not detected using the standard methods employed. It is important to consult with a geneticist or endocrinologist for further evaluation and genetic counseling.

In terms of fertility, women with Turner syndrome often have some level of ovarian function, even if they haven't started menstruating. However, fertility can vary depending on the specific type and severity of Turner syndrome. Assisted reproductive technologies, such as in vitro fertilization (IVF), may be options for women with Turner syndrome who wish to have biological children.

It is important for your sister to receive comprehensive medical care from a specialized team to address her specific health needs associated with Turner syndrome. They will be able to provide guidance on managing hormonal imbalances, growth issues, and potential complications related to this condition.

input: Hello doctor,I have a question about my voice. As a kid, I had a raspy voice the entire time until puberty. The problem I have is that I have to try quite hard to speak in a normal tone, and I am extremely self-conscious about the way I sound. I breathed through my mouth my entire life until I had a septoplasty three years back. Now I can breathe through one nostril, which I guess is 60 % open, while the other one is always 100 % blocked. What is happening, that is making me sound like this? I know I was not meant to sound this way, there has to be something causing some problem. Any idea or suggestion will be appreciated.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 34 year old male. I had anxiety issues since childhood. I have been jumping from one idea to another for a long time but it has been three years I have an issue with frequent urination. It started in a bad time for me when I was obsessing that I have HIV. No burning, just slight urethra burning. I went to a urologist. He told me nothing was wrong, maybe an overactive bladder. I go to the toilet every two hours or three. I never knew what was wrong, but I started to obsess over it and it got worse to a place that my mind is in urination 24/7. I almost gave up until I went on a vacation and during that vacation, I forgot about it totally. The frequency was gone and even the burning urethra. Also, I had to remove my wisdom teeth and when I did, I was so occupied thinking about it that I forgot about urination and I noticed that I do not use the bathroom like I used to. But, I got back obsessing about it again and it got to a point that I urinate a lot of high volumes every hour. It comes suddenly and goes on its own. I use to get those episodes every few months when I had stress but since I got the fear it might never go away I get it almost daily now. I do not know what to do. ### Response:As a doctor, I can provide some guidance on choosing the right sunblock cream for your needs. The term SPF (Sun Protection Factor) refers to the level of protection a sunscreen provides against ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation from the sun. 

SPF 15 blocks about 93% of UVB rays, while SPF 30 blocks around 97% of UVB rays, and SPF 60 blocks approximately 99.9% of UVB rays. Higher SPF numbers indicate higher levels of protection.

Considering your concerns about sun exposure during cricket games, I recommend using a sunscreen with an SPF of at least 50. This will provide excellent protection against UVB rays and help prevent sunburn and long-term skin damage caused by the sun.

Additionally, look for a sunscreen that is broad-spectrum, meaning it protects against both UVA and UVB rays. Apply the sunscreen generously to all exposed areas of skin, including your face, and reapply every two hours, especially if you are sweating or swimming.

Remember, while sunscreen is important, it should not replace other measures like seeking shade, wearing protective clothing (such as hats and long sleeves), and regularly checking for any signs of sunburn

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?

### Response:The regular contraceptive pill and the emergency contraceptive pill, such as the I-pill, have some key differences.

Regular contraceptive pills, also known as birth control pills, are taken regularly to prevent pregnancy. They contain hormones that work to inhibit ovulation, thicken cervical mucus, and thin the lining of the uterus. These pills must be taken consistently and at the same time every day in order to be effective.

On the other hand, emergency contraceptive pills, like the I-pill, are used after unprotected sex or if other methods of contraception fail. The I-pill contains a higher dose of progestin hormone compared to regular contraceptive pills. It works by delaying or inhibiting ovulation, preventing fertilization of the egg, or impairing implantation of a fertilized egg. It is important to note that the I-pill does not protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

In summary, the main difference between the regular contraceptive pill and the emergency contraceptive pill (such as the I-pill) is their intended use. The regular contraceptive pill is taken regularly to prevent pregnancy, while the emergency contraceptive pill is taken after unprotected sex

input: Hi doctor,My mom is 83 years old. She had a bad fall 1.5 years ago and suffered with a head injury with little internal bleeding and a broken arm. While in hospital, she contracted C.diff and has had several recurring bouts with it. She has had a transplant and so far she is doing well with no recurrence. She also has a fistula near the rectum from an abscess. They put in a tube to keep it open and flowing. She has always had bouts of constipation and diarrhea for years before the accident. Her cognitive functions have been diminishing. One of my brothers is living with her and care taking her for full time.She is very weak, but can walk with the aid of a walker. Before the accident, she was fine. But, she may have shown a few signs of slight memory issues and balance prior to the accident as well. Our main issue right now is loose stools with some fecal incontinence. The doctor said that the fecal incontinence is because of a weak rectum that will not hold back fecal matter. Also, the fistula is always draining. When her stools are normal, she has good energy and cognitive function. When she has loose stools, she is very weak and can hardly stand or walk. Her cognitive function is a lot worse. She gets very confused about daily items and memory issues.We are looking for supplements to keep her regular and avoid the loose stool episodes. These are recurring every other week. Being so weak at the time of an episode, the toilet and the surrounding area get very filthy. She has little control and not able to clean herself properly. Her diet is pretty good. We are trying to keep dairy items away, limiting sugar and some carbohydrates as best as we can.We are giving her Metamucil when she has loose stools as well as some ammonium. This seems to have very limited success. She is on a blood pressure medicine as well as on Coumadin. So, we have to watch for interactions between everything. Regarding supplements, right now she is taking Alpha-GPC, Prevagen and multivitamins B for cognitive help, Fish oil, turmeric and Centrum multivitamins.Any help or suggestions to prevent the loose stools without creating constipation would be appreciated. I would also like to increase her core energy, so she will feel more like moving around. We have a physical therapist at once a week.

input: Hi doctor,I am on Depot injection and I missed the shot for over 10 days now. I have not started bleeding yet. When I was on the shot before, I bled when I get off the shot. Now, how would I know if I am pregnant?
raw_output:

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am on Depot injection and I missed the shot for over 10 days now. I have not started bleeding yet. When I was on the shot before, I bled when I get off the shot. Now, how would I know if I am pregnant?

### Response:If you are missing periods and concerned about potential pregnancy, there are a few options for determining whether or not you are pregnant. One option is to take a home pregnancy test. These tests can be purchased at most pharmacies and work by detecting the presence of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in urine. hCG is a hormone produced during pregnancy. Another option is to visit a healthcare provider who can perform a blood test to measure the level of hCG in your system.

It's important to note that missing a few injections of the Depo-Provera contraceptive shot does not guarantee that you are not pregnant. The shot is designed to provide long-acting contraception, but it is still possible to become pregnant if the timing of injection misses is inconsistent. If you are concerned about pregnancy, it is best to consult with a healthcare provider who can help assess your individual situation and provide appropriate guidance.
response:
If you are missing periods and concerned about potential pregnancy, there are a few options for determining whether or not you are pregnant. One option is to take a home pregnancy test. These tests can be purchased at most pharmacies and work by detecting the presence of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in urine. hCG is a hormone produced during pregnancy. Another option is to visit a healthcare provider who can perform a blood test to measure the level of hCG in your system.

It's important to note that missing a few injections of the Depo-Provera contraceptive shot does not guarantee that you are not pregnant. The shot is designed to provide long-acting contraception, but it is still possible to become pregnant if the timing of injection misses is inconsistent. If you are concerned about pregnancy, it is best to consult with a healthcare provider who can help assess your individual situation and provide appropriate guidance.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I have a lot of black spots on my face and upper back due to the popping of pimples. To where it is darkening my skin making me uncomfortable with myself. I have been clueless about the medication I should use that would help my situation.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have a lot of black spots on my face and upper back due to the popping of pimples. To where it is darkening my skin making me uncomfortable with myself. I have been clueless about the medication I should use that would help my situation.

### Response:Based on your description, it seems like you are experiencing post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH). PIH is a common condition where the area of inflammation left behind after a pimple pops becomes darker than the surrounding skin.

To treat PIH, I recommend the following:

1. Avoid picking or popping pimples: This will help reduce further inflammation and minimize the chances of developing PIH.
2. Use gentle skincare products: Choose non-comedogenic (non-clogging) products that are suitable for your skin type. Look for ingredients like salicylic acid or benzoyl peroxide to help unclog pores and reduce acne.
3. Use sunscreen daily: Protect your skin from UV radiation, as it can worsen hyperpigmentation. Look for a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher.
4. Use topical treatments: Over-the-counter creams or gels containing ingredients like kojic acid, azelaic acid, retinoids, or hydroquinone can help lighten the dark spots over time. However, it's important to use these treatments as directed and under the guidance of a dermatologist to ensure safety and effectiveness.

I was advised to take bed rest for three months and felt better after five months. Then I got some manipulation done with my lower back and my condition got worse. After that I had slight pain in my tail bone while walking and the pain got worse when I sit for five minutes. It got radiated to hips, thighs and it was worse when I stood up from a sitting position. Then I left with no option except bed rest for another four months that is a total nine months of bed rest. After that I suddenly started walking two to three hours a day in a stretch and started doing some exercises. After few days of getting my body too much into motion I felt my upper back getting stuck and again was unable to move and the pain radiated to my wrist and hand. ### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is possible that they have angle-closure glaucoma. Angle-closure glaucoma occurs when there is a blockage in the drainage canals of the eye, leading to increased pressure inside the eye. This can result in decreased vision or vision loss.

The fact that the patient took a strong sleeping pill called Trazodone and experienced a decreased vision in the right eye the next day suggests a potential connection between the medication and the eye condition. It is known that certain medications, including Trazodone, can cause ocular side effects such as angle-closure glaucoma.

Furthermore, the patient's left eye becoming bad three weeks later indicates a progression of the condition. The normal fundus and other clinical examinations suggest that the visual impairment might not be related to any obvious abnormalities in these areas.

The findings of nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning on the OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography) are consistent with glaucoma. Glaucoma is characterized by damage to the optic nerve, which can be visualized using OCT.

In conclusion, based on the patient's symptoms, history, and test results, it is likely that they have angle-closure glaucoma.

raw_output:

### Input:
Hello doctor,A couple of my adult teeth feel loose. My gums are sore and bleed randomly as well as when I brush. Do I have gum disease?

### Response:Based on your symptoms of loose teeth and sore, bleeding gums, it is possible that you have gum disease. Gum disease, also known as periodontal disease, is an infection of the tissues that surround and support your teeth. It is caused by the buildup of plaque and tartar on the teeth and gum line.

To confirm whether you have gum disease, it is important to see a dentist for a thorough examination. The dentist will likely perform a periodontal probing to measure the depth of the pockets around your teeth and assess the health of your gums. They may also take X-rays to check for any bone damage.

Treatment for gum disease depends on the severity of the condition but may include deep cleaning (scaling and root planing), antibiotics, or even surgery. It is essential to seek professional advice and follow their recommendations for effective management of gum disease.

Please consult a dentist to get a proper diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. I have tried almost all SSRIs, and SNRIs and neither of them have worked for me (for the last 2 1/2 years). I believe that I have treatment-resistant depression because all the medicines are not working. Currently, I am taking 20 mg of Paroxetine (although I already took 40 mg a few months ago, so I already increased the dose as well), 900 mg of Lithium and 1.5 mg of Risperidone. What should I do?
raw_output:

Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. I have tried almost all SSRIs, and SNRIs and neither of them have worked for me (for the last 2 1/2 years). I believe that I have treatment-resistant depression because all the medicines are not working. Currently, I am taking 20 mg of Paroxetine (although I already took 40 mg a few months ago, so I already increased the dose as well), 900 mg of Lithium and 1.5 mg of Risperidone. What should I do?

### Response:I'm not a doctor, but I can offer some general information. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice. 

If you believe you have treatment-resistant depression, there are several options you can consider. One option is to try another class of antidepressant medication, such as tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) or atypical antidepressants. Your doctor may also consider adding adjunctive medications, such as atypical antipsychotics or lithium.

It's worth discussing with your doctor the possibility of undergoing further evaluations, such as genetic testing or neurostimulation therapies like ECT or TMS. Psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), may also be beneficial in managing symptoms of depression and anxiety.

Remember that each individual is different, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to work closely with your healthcare team to find the most effective treatment plan for you.

input: Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.

### Response:As a doctor, I can understand your concerns regarding the recommendation for a nuclear stress echo instead of a regular exercise stress echo. However, it is important to note that the choice of stress test modality depends on various factors and individual patient characteristics.

In patients with left branch bundle block (LBBB), which is a conduction abnormality in the heart, the accuracy of exercise stress echocardiography may be limited. This is because LBBB can affect the accuracy of assessing blood flow and heart function during exercise. In such cases, alternative modalities like chemical or nuclear stress tests may be recommended to evaluate heart function more accurately.

I and my fiance have been discussing and are planning to have a baby. I am concerned if I am able to have a VBAC delivery with my second pregnancy since my first pregnancy resulted in an emergency C-section. Also, I am 48. What are the risks of pregnancy in women over 40?

I and my fiance have been discussing and are planning to have a baby. I am concerned if I am able to have a VBAC delivery with my second pregnancy since my first pregnancy resulted in an emergency C-section. Also, I am 48. What are the risks of pregnancy in women over 40?

### Response:As a doctor, I can provide you with some information regarding your concerns about having a VBAC delivery and the risks of pregnancy in women over 40.

1. VBAC (vaginal birth after cesarean) delivery:
   - It is possible to attempt a VBAC delivery after a previous cesarean section. However, the decision will depend on various factors including the type of incision made during the previous surgery, any complications during the first pregnancy, and overall health status.
   - The success rate of having a VBAC delivery varies and may depend on individual circumstances.
   - It is important to discuss your desire for a VBAC delivery with your healthcare provider who can assess your specific case and give you more accurate information regarding the possibility and potential risks involved.

2. Pregnancy in women over 40:
   - Women over the age of 40 have an increased risk of certain complications compared to younger women.
   - Some of the potential risks include difficulties getting pregnant, higher chance of miscarriage, increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus (such as Down syndrome), and a higher likelihood of developing pregnancy-related conditions like gestational diabetes or preeclampsia.
   - Older women are also at a greater risk of having a multiple pregnancy

input: Hello doctor,I have a lazy eye. My right eye (sph - 0.50 cyl -0.75 axis 10 degrees) and the left eye is fine. I am 24 years old. I am a web developer, I have to work in front of the computer screen more than 13 hours. Kindly answer the following:What should I do? Do I need to change my profession?Is it curable? What is the treatment?Is there any chance of getting other eye affected?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have a lazy eye. My right eye (sph - 0.50 cyl -0.75 axis 10 degrees) and the left eye is fine. I am 24 years old. I am a web developer, I have to work in front of the computer screen more than 13 hours. Kindly answer the following:What should I do? Do I need to change my profession?Is it curable? What is the treatment?Is there any chance of getting other eye affected?

### Response:Based on the information provided, it appears that you have a condition called strabismus, specifically a lazy eye (esotropia) with fused rectus muscles. This means that your right eye deviates inward towards your nose and you have a refractive error in that eye.

As a medical expert, I would recommend consulting with an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management. They will be able to assess the severity of your condition and determine the most appropriate treatment options. Treatment for strabismus often involves a combination of glasses, prisms, eye patching, and sometimes surgery, depending on the specific case.

Regarding your concerns about working in front of a computer screen for long hours, it is important to take regular breaks and practice good ergonomics to prevent eye strain or any other related symptoms. However, changing your profession may not be necessary solely based on this condition. Many individuals with strabismus are able to lead successful careers without any issues related to their eye condition.

It is important to note that early intervention and treatment increase the chances of improving the alignment and function of your eyes. Therefore, seeking medical attention from an ophthalmologist is crucial in order to prevent any complications and address any concerns you may have.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, there are a few possible reasons for breast leakage during intercourse. One common cause could be sexual arousal or stimulation, which can lead to the release of sexual fluids from the breasts. This is perfectly normal and not necessarily a cause for concern.

Another potential reason could be hormonal changes. Fluctuations in hormone levels, especially during the menstrual cycle, can cause breast tenderness and milk production. It is possible that sexual activity may exacerbate these natural processes.

However, it is important to rule out any underlying medical conditions that could be contributing to the breast leakage. Conditions such as fibrocystic breast disease or a hormonal imbalance may result in persistent or abnormal breast discharge.

I would recommend the patient to consult with a healthcare professional, preferably a gynecologist or obstetrician, who can conduct a thorough examination and medical history assessment. This will help determine the exact cause of the breast leakage and provide appropriate treatment or recommendations.

### Input:
Hi doctor,My son is 16 years old. He is suffering from constipation. What are the home remedies used to get rid of it?

### Response:There are several home remedies that can help relieve constipation in teenagers. Here are a few options:

1. Increase fiber intake: Encourage your son to eat more fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, as they are high in fiber. Good sources include apples, oranges, carrots, broccoli, and brown rice.

2. Stay hydrated: Adequate fluid intake is important for maintaining regular bowel movements. Make sure your son drinks enough water throughout the day.

3. Physical activity: Encourage your son to engage in regular physical activity, as it can help stimulate bowel movements.

4. Warm bath: A warm bath with Epsom salts may help relax the muscles and promote bowel movements.

5. Avoid dairy products: Some individuals may experience constipation due to lactose intolerance. Consider reducing or avoiding dairy products in your son's diet and opt for lactose-free alternatives if needed.

It is important to note that if these home remedies do not provide relief within a few days or if symptoms worsen, it would be best to consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation and guidance.

His optometrist changed the type of lens after remarking that the lens appeared tight. Although the painful sensations have decreased, they are still present with more of a sore feeling now. His ophthalmologist suggested that he discontinue the Azopt drops he had been using in case the preservative was causing some corneal toxicity. His eye pressure without the drops has read at 18 and 20 on separate occasions, but he does have corneal edema which may affect the measurement. He has had high pressure in that eye previously, but it was mostly lowered by Cyclodiode treatment some eight years ago. The consultant said he had left him on the Azopt drops just as a precaution. My query is that if the bandage lens has worked so well for pain management for 10 years is it possible that it can continue to work? And if the Azopt drops and their preservative had caused some toxic reaction seven months ago, could that still be causing him to feel the discomfort? His consultant suggested out that he could have the eye removed to control the pain, but as he has what he feels is some slight, useful vision in that eye, he does not want to take such a drastic and life-changing step. ### Response:Based on the patient's description, the presence of froth in urine and facial puffiness could be indicative of a potential kidney problem. These symptoms may be associated with a condition known as nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria (excess protein in the urine), edema (facial puffiness), and abnormal liver function tests.

I would recommend the following further management steps:
1. Check urine for protein: Test for urine protein using a urine dipstick test or sending a sample for laboratory analysis. This will help determine if there is excess protein in the urine, which is an important diagnostic marker for nephrotic syndrome.
2. Perform ultrasound abdomen: An ultrasound of the abdomen can provide information about the size and structure of the kidneys, as well as detect any abnormalities or signs of fluid accumulation.
3. Repeat renal function tests (RFT): While you mentioned that your previous RFT results were normal, it would be helpful to repeat these tests to assess overall kidney function and look for any changes.
4. Consult a nephrologist: Consider seeking the opinion of a nephrologist, who specializes in kidney diseases. They will be able to evaluate your symptoms, test results, and provide appropriate guidance

Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that develops when melanocytes (the cells that produce pigment in your skin) grow uncontrollably. It can appear as a new mole or an existing mole may change in size, shape, or color.

To determine if the mark in your picture is melanoma, it is essential to consider the ABCDE signs:

A - Asymmetry: Melanomas have irregular shapes and are usually asymmetric.
B - Border: Melanoma borders tend to be uneven or undefined.
C - Color: Melanomas often have varied colors within the same mole.
D - Diameter: Melanomas are usually larger than 6 millimeters (about the size of a pencil eraser).
E - Evolution: Pay attention to any changes in size, shape, color, or symptoms such as itching or bleeding.

If you notice any suspicious changes in your skin, it is recommended to consult a dermatologist who can conduct a thorough examination and provide a proper diagnosis. They may also suggest further tests, such as a biopsy, if necessary.

1. Is hepatitis B transmitted by saliva?
Hepatitis B is not typically transmitted by saliva. The virus is mainly transmitted through contact with infected blood, semen, or vaginal fluids. It can be transmitted through activities such as unprotected sexual contact, sharing needles, or from mother to baby during childbirth.

2. Hepatitis B virus has just been detected in your body and your viral load is 1.5 * 10^5 count/mL.

Hepatitis B can be treated but not always completely cured. With appropriate treatment, the replication of the virus can be suppressed, leading to improved liver function and overall health. However, some people may have ongoing liver complications even with successful treatment.

4. If it is possible, how much time will it take to get totally cured?
The duration of treatment and the time it takes to achieve total clearance of the virus can vary depending on various factors, including the individual's overall health, viral

input: Hi doctor,I have just received results back from a blood test that says my red blood cell count is quite high. I am a 35-year-old female and I am a smoker (between 4 to 7 a day). I began to get headaches, dizzy spells, nausea, fatigue, and itchiness all over the past five weeks. I do not know whether or not a miscarriage could count towards what is going on or not but I would like to know what it is I should do. My doctor just said to quit smoking and come back in 12 weeks for another test.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hi doctor,I have just received results back from a blood test that says my red blood cell count is quite high. I am a 35-year-old female and I am a smoker (between 4 to 7 a day). I began to get headaches, dizzy spells, nausea, fatigue, and itchiness all over the past five weeks. I do not know whether or not a miscarriage could count towards what is going on or not but I would like to know what it is I should do. My doctor just said to quit smoking and come back in 12 weeks for another test.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, high red blood cell count, headaches, dizzy spells, nausea, fatigue, and itchiness all over, along with the fact that she is a smoker, it is important to consider several possible causes.

One possibility could be chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which can cause increased red blood cell production due to decreased oxygen levels in the bloodstream. This could explain the high red blood cell count. The symptoms of headaches, dizziness, and fatigue could be related to the decreased oxygen levels as well.

Another possibility is iron overload or iron deficiency anemia. Smoking has been associated with both conditions. Iron overload can occur due to conditions like hemochromatosis, while iron deficiency anemia can result from inadequate dietary intake or chronic bleeding. Both conditions can lead to an increase in red blood cell count.

It is also important to consider other potential causes such as anemia of chronic disease, thalassemia, or primary polycythemia vera. These conditions will require further investigation by your doctor.

Given the patient's symptoms and risk factors, it would be prudent to investigate further by ordering additional tests such as complete blood count (CBC), reticulocyte count, iron studies

Presently, the doctor told her to take Aspirin 150 mg, folic acid, and Vitamin B12 combination tablet and to try for pregnancy again. I want your valuable opinion regarding subsequent management or the right line of treatment and suggestions or tests (if any) to get a successful pregnancy and healthy baby.

raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I am 31 year old male. My eardrum burst after coming down with the flu. It has been leaking this watery bloody substance. This happened about four hours ago. I was in pain till it burst. Seems like all the pressure went away and was a huge relief. My question is do I let it heal on its own or should I go see a doctor?

### Response:Based on your description, it appears that you have a ruptured eardrum. This can occur due to the pressure build-up caused by an infection, such as the flu. The watery bloody substance leaking from the ear is likely blood and fluid that has accumulated behind the eardrum.

While ruptured eardrums can heal on their own, it is generally recommended to seek medical attention for the following reasons:

input: Hello doctor,I had a question about the ketone diet. I honestly do not understand the benefits of a ketone diet, what are they? Is a ketone diet good for those who are diabetic?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I had a question about the ketone diet. I honestly do not understand the benefits of a ketone diet, what are they? Is a ketone diet good for those who are diabetic?

### Response:The ketone diet is a low-carbohydrate, high-fat diet that aims to induce a metabolic state called ketosis. In this state, the body relies primarily on fat for energy instead of carbohydrates. 

The claimed benefits of a ketone diet include weight loss, improved brain function, increased energy levels, and reduced inflammation. Some proponents also suggest that it may help manage certain medical conditions such as epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, and type 2 diabetes.

For individuals with diabetes, a ketone diet can be beneficial in certain cases. When carbohydrates are restricted, blood sugar levels tend to stabilize, which can improve glycemic control. Additionally, a ketone diet may promote weight loss, which is important for individuals with type 2 diabetes.

However, it is essential for individuals with diabetes to closely monitor their blood sugar levels and work with their healthcare provider to adjust medications as needed. Furthermore, it should be noted that the long-term safety and effectiveness of a ketone diet for diabetes management has not been extensively studied.

As always, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional before making any significant changes to your diet or treatment plan.

I got an ultrasound done, and it shows 4.5 cm cyst in my right ovary. Why am I having pain on my left side when the cyst is on the right? Could this pain be due to the cyst?

### Response:Hello,

Thank you for your question. Pain on the left side even though there is a cyst on the right ovary can still be related to the cyst. The ovaries are situated on either side of the uterus, and pain from one ovary can sometimes refer or be felt on the opposite side. This is known as "referred pain."

In your case, it is possible that the cyst in your right ovary is causing irritation or inflammation in the nearby areas, including the left ovary and pelvic structures. This irritation or inflammation can lead to discomfort or pain in the left pelvic area.

Additionally, it is important to note that the ovaries are connected to each other by ligaments, and movement of the cyst on the right ovary may also contribute to pain on the left side.

It is recommended that you consult with your healthcare provider for further evaluation and management of your symptoms. They may recommend additional tests, such as blood work or a physical examination, to assess the severity of the cyst and determine the appropriate treatment plan.

input: Hi doctor,My 4 years son had a cough for two days. Now his cough is fine but now he has a high fever on the head side but his hands are ice cold. He is telling pain sometimes in hands and some times in feet. What is the cause? Please explain.
raw_output:

### Instruction:

### Input:
Hi doctor,My 4 years son had a cough for two days. Now his cough is fine but now he has a high fever on the head side but his hands are ice cold. He is telling pain sometimes in hands and some times in feet. What is the cause? Please explain.

### Response:Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that your son is experiencing a viral infection. The cough suggests a respiratory infection, and the fever on the head side indicates that the infection may have spread to the central nervous system.

The ice cold hands and feet along with occasional pain in the hands and feet could be signs of peripheral circulatory problems, also known as peripheral cyanosis. This can occur when blood vessels constrict in response to the body's attempt to divert blood flow away from nonessential areas to the core body temperature.

It is important to monitor your son's symptoms closely and seek medical attention if they worsen or persist for an extended period of time.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor, I have been taking Effexor XR 300 mg for depression. It has been working really well. My psychiatrist has now prescribed me Strattera for ADHD. I am about to start 25 mg and work my way upto 80 mg over a few weeks. Strattera and Effexor both seem to inhibit Norepinephrine reuptake. Is it safe to take this combination? I know my psychiatrist knows what he is doing, but I wanted to get a second opinion from others.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor, I have been taking Effexor XR 300 mg for depression. It has been working really well. My psychiatrist has now prescribed me Strattera for ADHD. I am about to start 25 mg and work my way upto 80 mg over a few weeks. Strattera and Effexor both seem to inhibit Norepinephrine reuptake. Is it safe to take this combination? I know my psychiatrist knows what he is doing, but I wanted to get a second opinion from others.

### Response:As a medical expert, I can provide some information regarding your question. 

Strattera (atomoxetine) and Effexor XR (venlafaxine) both affect the reuptake of norepinephrine in the brain. However, they do so through different mechanisms. While Strattera is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), Effexor XR is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI).

Taking both medications together can potentially increase the levels of norepinephrine in the brain, which may lead to increased side effects or adverse reactions. Some common side effects associated with increased norepinephrine activity include nervousness, anxiety, restlessness, and insomnia.

It is important to note that every individual responds differently to medications, and what may work well for one person may not be suitable for another. It is always recommended to consult with your prescribing physician or psychiatrist regarding any concerns or questions about medication combinations.

In summary, while your psychiatrist may be knowledgeable and experienced, it is advisable to discuss the potential risks and benefits of combining Strattera and Effexor XR before starting or adjusting the dosage of these medications.
